awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Bridging genomics, physiology, and behavioral ecology to uncover mechanisms driving incipient speciation in an island bird
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Combining studies of behavior and physiology with genomic data, the research will enhance understanding about new species arising in isolated habitats. The project focuses on a group of birds, Monarcha flycatchers, found only in the Solomon Islands in the South Pacific. On the smaller islands of the archipelago, previous research uncovered repeated evolution of all black (melanic) coloration from chestnut colored ancestors. In most populations where this occurred, all birds are now melanic and mate only with other melanic individuals, resulting in a new species. The reasons for color differences across islands are unknown. To determine what is underlying the evolution of black coloration, the fellow will study an island population in which both melanic and chestnut colored birds still exist and mate with each other. This will provide insight into processes that drive evolution of novel traits and the origin of species. Knowing how behavior, physiology, and genetics interact to influence species evolution will facilitate appreciation and preservation of the world’s remarkable biodiversity. To broaden the impact of the project, a case study will be designed for high school students about how species evolve. 

Understanding how and why visual signals change in the context of incipient speciation is crucial to discerning drivers of population divergence. In a population polymorphic for two distinct visual signals – melanic and chestnut coloration – this project tests three alternative hypotheses explaining repeated evolution of melanism in the Monarcha clade. Melanism may be under indirect selection due to pleiotropic effects of the melanocortin system, and associations with testosterone and/or aggression. Alternatively, interaction and competition with conspecifics may drive social selection for melanism. Finally, melanism may arise through genetic drift via small populations and minimal negative pleiotropy. Testing predictions of these hypotheses involves three aims: (1) determine effects of plumage color on aggressive behavior through mount presentation experiments; (2) characterize the evolutionary processes mediating and genetic architecture underlying melanism using whole-genome resequencing data; and (3) measure alpha-Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone and testosterone in melanic, chestnut, and plumage-manipulated birds. The fellow will benefit from in-depth experience integrating whole-genome analyses with phenotypic, behavioral, and physiological responses. In addition, this study will be featured in a case study designed to educate high school students about speciation, convergent evolution, and the scientific process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The origin of species – speciation – is a fundamental evolutionary process responsible for the diversity of life forms we see around us. Generally, we identify different species based on their appearance, behavior, and whether they mate with each other. Increasingly, however, biologists are uncovering evidence of interbreeding – hybridization – between what we think of as distinct species. The frequency and outcomes of hybridization events can be extremely useful in understanding what factors define species boundaries, providing a “moment of truth” for speciation in the words of influential evolutionary biologist Ernst Mayr. One such moment of truth is playing out between two bird species in the remote Solomon Islands of the South Pacific. The red Cardinal Honeyeater (Myzomela cardinalis) and the black Sooty Honeyeater (Myzomela tristrami) coexist on the island of Makira. These two species are different in appearance but have similar behavior and appear to interbreed, as individuals with a mixture of red and black feathers have been captured since the mid-20th century. The history of contact and similarities in these species provide a perfect opportunity to use genetic tools as well as field observations to understand what aspects of these birds’ biology prevents or facilitates hybridization.

During this NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship, I studied the genetic and behavioral patterns of interbreeding between Cardinal and Sooty Honeyeaters in the Solomon Islands. I sequenced and analyzed previously collected samples and also conducted three seasons of field work, collecting and sequencing additional genetic samples in addition to recording data on mating and nesting behavior. Using genetic data, I found that the two species can interbreed, as several individuals carried genetic information from both species. However, I also uncovered evidence of asymmetric interbreeding. Based on the sex-specific chromosomes, I found that while Cardinal Honeyeater females appear to mate successfully with Sooty Honeyeater males, no individuals in the population appear to be the result of a mating between a Sooty Honeyeater female and Cardinal Honeyeater male. This could be due to distinct mating preferences if Sooty Honeyeater females choose not to mate with Cardinal Honeyeater males. Alternatively, matings between those individuals may be unsuccessful due to incompatible genetic combinations. To disentangle these possibilities, I collected data on mate pairing and nesting behavior. Analyses of these data are ongoing, but I anticipate incorporating field and behavioral observations with bioinformatic genetic information will provide greater insight to the factors which maintain the distinct identities of these two species.

As an NSF postdoctoral fellow under the mentorship of Drs. Al Uy, Daven Presgraves, and Nancy Chen at the University of Rochester, I was able to broaden my skillset to include speciation and population genetics analyses. This theoretical and analytical background builds upon my doctoral training in behavioral ecology and has prepared me to start a research program as a tenure-track faculty member at Wake Forest University; I plan to test hypotheses about speciation and hybridization that incorporate detailed field observations with cutting edge genomic technologies. I have had the opportunity to mentor an undergraduate through completion of an honor’s thesis, resulting in a manuscript that will be submitted for peer-review. In addition to the published work characterizing the genomic patterns in the system, I have three additional manuscripts in preparation, to be submitted for publication in 2025. During the award period I presented my work in seven invited seminars and eight national and international conferences. I also made it a priority to share my research goals and findings in the Solomon Islands where the data was collected. I offered shadowing opportunities for high school students and presented regularly at community gatherings and school assemblies to foster education, communication, and engagement between the research team and the local community.
